summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued to Ghislaine Maxwell by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, commanding her to appear and testify on July 24, 2019, regarding alleged violations of federal sex trafficking and conspiracy statutes. It includes an attached 'Advice of Rights' and a cover letter requesting confidentiality.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: She is commanded to appear before the grand jury to testify and produce items in connection with an investigation into alleged violations of federal sex trafficking and related statutes.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: He signed the subpoena and the accompanying cover letter requesting confidentiality of the investigation.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, is issuing a grand jury subpoena to Maxwell as part of a federal criminal investigation.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is commanded to appear before the grand jury at the U.S. Courthouse in Manhattan to testify and give evidence.

events.title: Issuance of Grand Jury Subpoena
events.description: The subpoena is dated and issued to Ghislaine Maxwell by the U.S. Attorney's Office.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, New York
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was subpoenaed to appear before a federal grand jury on July 24, 2019, in the Southern District of New York.

The investigation concerned alleged violations of federal statutes including 18 U.S.C. §§ 1591 (sex trafficking), 2421-2423 (transportation for prostitution, coercion, and minors), and 371 (conspiracy).
The U.S. Attorney's Office requested Maxwell voluntarily refrain from disclosing the existence of the subpoena to preserve the investigation's confidentiality.
The document includes a formal 'Advice of Rights' informing Maxwell of her right against self-incrimination and right to counsel.
The subpoena was issued and signed by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman.
